results.headline: A Standoff Between Longing and Denial

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Good Dick

results.summary_short: Dysfunction beguiles in “Good Dick,” a perverse romantic comedy whose coarse title belies its tender heart.

results.headline: Dysfunctional Americans Abroad

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Elephant King

results.summary_short: There is in fact an elephant in “The Elephant King,” but his keepers are far from royal.

results.headline: A Middle Eastern Animated Tale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Azur & Asmar

results.summary_short: “Azur & Asmar” unfolds in a flat, storybook style worlds away from the sculptured digital aesthetic pioneered by Pixar and emulated by everyone else.

results.headline: A Satirical Look at Hollywood Lives, Viewed Through a Cynical Lens

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What Just Happened?

results.summary_short: The title of Barry Levinson’s new movie, “What Just Happened,” is not phrased as a question, but if it were it would demand another question in response: “Who cares?”

results.headline: The Competing Demands of Muse and Family
results.display_title: Who Does She Think She Is?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Who Does She Think She Is?

results.summary_short: “Who Does She Think She Is?” is an engaging documentary about the struggle to create art while nurturing life.

results.headline: A Lone Avenger, Jampacked With Righteous Anger

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Max Payne

results.summary_short: “Max Payne” is content to be an efficient vehicle for the delivery of a familiar range of sensations, some of which almost rise to the level of feelings.

results.headline: Scot. Joe Scot.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flashbacks of a Fool

results.summary_short: Without Daniel Craig’s 007-enhanced profile, it’s unlikely that “Flashbacks of a Fool” would have appeared anywhere except the Netflix queues of his most rabid fans.

results.headline: Stripping and Other Noble Pursuits

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Filth and Wisdom

results.summary_short: Pop go the dialectics in “Filth and Wisdom,” a tale of bumping and grinding your way to happiness from the hardest-working hard body in show business.

results.headline: Public Displays of Hormonally Charged Desperation

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sex Drive

results.summary_short: The most notable thing about “Sex Drive” is that it reserves all its creativity for ways to revolt and ostensibly delight its target audience.

results.headline: Two Friends With Tall Tales

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Not Your Typical Bigfoot Movie

results.summary_short: In the once booming, now fading steel town of Portsmouth, Ohio, two friends share a talent for spotting the apelike creature most popularly known as Bigfoot.

results.headline: A Golden Dollop of Motherly Comfort

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Secret Life of Bees

results.summary_short: “The Secret Life of Bees” insists so strenuously on its themes of redemption, tolerance, love and healing that it winds up defeating itself.

results.headline: Running for Office, With Class

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of FrontRunners

results.summary_short: Without forcing comparisons, “Frontrunners” finds parallels between the election at Stuyvesant High and the current national election.

results.headline: Infection’s Bad Symptoms

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Quarantine

results.summary_short: “Quarantine,” yet another pseudo-documentary horror movie, delivers the heebie-jeebies with solid acting and perfectly calibrated shocks.

results.headline: The Upside of Seeing the Bright Side

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Happy-Go-Lucky

results.summary_short: “Happy-Go-Lucky” is closely tuned to the pulse of communal life, to the rhythms of how people work, play and struggle together.

results.headline: Aspirations That Go Beyond Gangsterism

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Talento de Barrio

results.summary_short: Daddy Yankee, a big star in the musical genre of reggaetón, takes his big-screen shot in “Talento de Barrio.”

results.headline: Gay Jock Meets Girlie-Boy and Bonding Is Awkward

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Breakfast With Scot

results.summary_short: In “Breakfast With Scot,” an effeminate 11-year-old boy who loves boas, beads and Broadway musicals is taken in by a semi-closeted gay male couple.

results.headline: Seeking a Connection in a Barren Place

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of La Leon

results.summary_short: Moonlight, mist and thick tropical air permeate the landscape of “La León,” a sumptuous film about the swirling of desire in the Paraná Delta.

results.headline: Politically Incorrect

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Choose Connor

results.summary_short: Written and directed with unrelenting cynicism by 22-year-old Luke Eberl, “Choose Connor” is undeniably obvious and intermittently awkward.

results.headline: The Gulf Between Persona and True Self

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nights and Weekends

results.summary_short: “Night and Weekends” observes the failing days of a relationship and an awkward, post-breakup reunion.

results.headline: Big Stars Wielding an Array of Accents, Fighting the War on Terrorism

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Body of Lies

results.summary_short: Ridley Scott’s new movie, “Body of Lies,” raises a potentially disturbing question. If terrorism has become boring, does that mean the terrorists have won?
